The attention of the Cabinet was drawn tothe fact that in giving the Answer to Questions onthe subject of Economy Cuts in the House of commons on the previous day, the Prime Minister had omittedthe following words from the Answer as approved bythe Cabinet at the Meeting referred to in the margin:- "I may add that no increase in these cutshas been considered by the Government",The Cabinet were reminded that by sub-heads(b) and (c) of the Conclusion referred to in the margin, Ministers had been invited to consider thedraft Answer carefully and, if they saw objection,to communicate with the Prime Minister, who, inconsultation with the Chancellor of the Exchequer,was to have authority to vary the wording.The Chancellor of the Exchequer informed theCabinet that almost at the last moment he had learned of an objection urged by the Secretary ofState for Scotland, to meet which, in the short time available, he had felt that there was no alternative but to omit the reference to possible future cuts. .In the course of a short discussion theSecretary of State for Scotland indicated that he did not contemplate any cuts beyond the 10 per cent,which had been mentioned in the Prime ministers statement of September 21, 1931.The Prime Minister suggested that in answeringquestions on this subject his colleagues should be careful not to announce that there would be no furthercuts and to keep within the limits of *j.-units of his statementof September 81, 1931, that the simplest way of removing just grievances is to limit reductionsas regards teachers, police and the three defence services, to not more than 10 per cent. MANCHURIA. 8, The Secretary of State for Foreign affairs drew attention to the false rumours that were being.(Re?Irence: spread in China about British policy at Geneva(llfToon- in the Chin Japanese dispute over Manchuria,elusion 5.) example, a story had been spread that, we had entered into a bargain with Japan whereby, inreturn for a free hand to her in Manchuria, weshould have a free hand in Tibet. There was, ofcourse, absolutely no truth in this suggestion.Nevertheless, these false rumours were having a dangerous effect in China, where there was a particularly pernicious Student Movement. At thesuggestion of the President of the Board of Tradehe himself had seen Mr Swire, the well-known Chinamerchant, that morning, and this gentleman had undertaken to send a telegram to Shanghai with aview to doing what was possible to quiet thingsdown. Sir Miles Lamps on reported that the Chinesewere getting somewhat hysterical, and there appearedto be a risk of a boycott of British goods, as in1925, for which there was absolutely no justifica-tion. At his instance, Reuters Agency were doing their best to correct false impressions. He had also sent messages to the Parliamentary UnderSecretary of State at Geneva, with the same object.Nevertheless, he was somewhat anxious as to thesituation, particularly in its commercial aspects.The present position, the Secretary of Stateexplained, was that the League was now passing outof the conciliation stage and that almost certainlya Report would" have to be produced, -he parliamentary under Secretary of State was taking part in the drafting of that Report. The general trend ofopinion at Geneva was, first, that Japan had broken-3- the Covenant, and, second, that no recognition ofManchukuo could be contemplated. He did not think we could avoid taking part in conclusions to this effect. As regards the second of the above pointshe proposed, in supporting the proposition, to makethe suggestion that if, in the future, circumstancesso develop as to require that this matter should befurther considered, His Majesty's Government do not wish to act in isolation but would seek to apply the spirit of Article VII of the Mine-Power Treatyso that there shall be the opportunity of communica-tion between the members of the League and the signatories to the Nine-Power Treaty in advance ofany decision that any member of the League might be disposed to take. This statement, of course, wouldhe made on the basis that other Powers, whethermembers of the League or not, agreed to act in thesame way. He believed that it was essential to agreeat Geneva to the two points to which he had justreferred, if serious trouble in China was to be avoided. The Japanese, he thought, could hardlyobject to our adopting this line, as he had alwayswarned their Delegation at Geneva that if coneilia-tion did not succeed we should have to act as goodmembers of the League of Nations. British publicopinion hitherto had perhaps been somewhat pro-Japanese, but if the Japanese took action which involved the occupation of Tientsin and Peking it was likely to change.The President of the Board of Trade emphasised the strong feeling that was growing up, particularlyin Lancashire, against Japan in consequence of her-4- very severe competition with British industry.The Secretary of State for the Coloniesindicated that he had done his best to prepareopinion in the Colonial Empire for the possiblenecessity of our having to take special measuresto meet Japanese competition, which was veryserious in some Colonies, and particularly in ceylon.In reply to questions, the Secretary of Statefor Foreign Affairs made it quite clear that if circumstances rendered it necessary, we werenot precluded from recognising Manchukuo, butthat we should first have to consult members ofthe League and the signatories of the Nine-PowerTreaty. China, of course, would like us to gomuch further and to apply Article XVI of theCovenant, but there could be no question of this.He thought, however, that if we participated inthe LeagueTs Report on the lines he had suggested,that should help to alleviate the situation.Enquiry was made as to the reasons why theChinese Delegation at Geneva was so active instirring up opinion against this country, and itwas suggested, that the aim was to play on theBritish commercial community in Shanghai to put pressure on the Government.The Cabinet approved generally the policy ofthe Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs as setforth above, and the Secretary of State for PoreigiAffairs said he had noted especially a suggestion by the Prime Minister that very close touch shouldbe kept both here and in Geneva with the Chineserepres representatives .
